pullRequest.body:
The file `NormedSpace.ProdLp` is copied from `NormedSpace.PiLp` with a two changes
- For `p = 0` we define the distance by using and if-else block which in turn makes it necessary to add some classicality assumptions
- We omit the sections about basis and constant maps

---

The file `InnerProductSpace.ProdL2` will contain more things later on, this is also why I imported `InnerProductSpace.Projection` since for the adjoint I need the properties of the orthogonal complement on products.

<!-- The text above the `---` will become the commit message when your
PR is merged. Please leave a blank newline before the `---`, otherwise
GitHub will format the text above it as a title.

To indicate co-authors, include lines at the bottom of the commit message
(that is, before the `---`) using the following format:

Co-authored-by: Author Name <author@email.com>

Any other comments you want to keep out of the PR commit should go
below the `---`, and placed outside this HTML comment, or else they
will be invisible to reviewers.

If this PR depends on other PRs, please list them below this comment,
using the following format:
- [ ] depends on: #abc [optional extra text]
- [ ] depends on: #xyz [optional extra text]
-->

nodes.body: I think it would be good to wait until #6409 is merged (or else thrown out), but I'll have an in-depth look after that.
One thing I forgot: please add a `CompleteSpace` instance after you define the uniform space structure.

> One thing I forgot: please add a `CompleteSpace` instance after you define the uniform space structure.

done
Please update the PR description with the correct statement about `p = 0`.
Sorry for the delay. I have been very busy the previous weeks, but now I am on vacation and I can do mathlib-stuff again.
@mcdoll if you make this build I am ready to merge it, but please merge master first.
@j-loreaux, I'm not sure how to rectify that comment with your comment above. Do you want to see the L2 lemmas moved back first, or are you happy to merge it either way?
Sorry, that was unclear. I'm ready to merge it modulo moving the lemmas back.

:v: mcdoll can now approve this pull request. To approve and merge a pull request, simply reply with `bors r+`. More detailed instructions are available [here](https://bors.tech/documentation/getting-started/#reviewing-pull-requests).
bors merge

bors d+
Thanks!
Thanks for this undertaking Moritz! It will be nice to actually have this!
Looks great, thanks!

bors d+
Thanks!
Shouldn't this be the count of differing elements for p=0?

```suggestion
    if _hp : p = 0 then
        (if f.fst = g.fst then 0 else 1) + (if f.snd = g.snd then 0 else 1)
```
I don't know, `PiLp` does this, but everything is basically developed only for `p > 0`.
I don't see what you mean by that; all the normed instances are in place for any `p`.
This lemma should not exist, as stated by the comment above.
This should now be deleted in favor of `WithLp.equiv`
This can now go too, in favor of `WithLp p (α × β)`
You don't mention how it is defined for `p = 0`. Please do.
I think these need `prod` in the name

I'm confused, why does this need `open Classical in`, but [PiLp.instEDistPiLp](https://leanprover-community.github.io/mathlib4_docs/Mathlib/Analysis/NormedSpace/PiLp.html#PiLp.instEDistPiLp) doesn't? Is it just because of the `if` statements on `α` and `β`? It might be nice to avoid a design that requires introducing the `Classical.decidableEq` things into the definition.
I think `Classical.decidableEq` (or worse) is hidden away inside `.toFinite.toFinset` in the `PiLp` version (so there's nothing really to worry about here).

```suggestion
      ENNReal.zero_rpow_of_pos (inv_pos.2 <| h)]
```
since this includes two `.trans`, it's probably more readable as a `calc` block, and maybe you could even close the goals with `gcongr`.
I don't think there is a convenient `calc` proof here: `sup_le` generates two goals and both of them are relatively trivial.

```suggestion
    edist f.fst g.fst ⊔ edist f.snd g.snd ≠ ⊤ :=
  ne_of_lt <| by simp [edist, PseudoMetricSpace.edist_dist]
```

```suggestion
        refine ENNReal.rpow_ne_top_of_nonneg (by positivity) (ne_of_lt ?_)
```

```suggestion
    simp only [edist, forall_prop_of_true, one_mul, ENNReal.coe_one, ge_iff_le, sup_le_iff]
```

Presumably this was an `exact?` call?
```suggestion
```

As Anatole remarked in #5742, it's probably even better to avoid defeq abuse even here, and instead pullback the uniform structure through `WithLp.equiv`.
```suggestion
instance instUniformSpace [UniformSpace α] [UniformSpace β] : UniformSpace (WithLp p (α × β)) :=
  instUniformSpaceProd
```

Maybe we should do this at the same time for the pi and the prod version? I've played around doing it for pi and there a few errors here and there, so I would suggest we do this after this PR. Similarly I start to think that all these instances should be in `WithLp`.

Yes, I think putting the topology and uniform space (and bornology probably) in `WithLp` probably makes sense. I think the whole point of `WithLp p α` is that it's `α`, except you replace the norm structure with Lp, and leave everything else untouched.

I'm okay if we leave the defeq abuse until a future PR. Yes, it does require a (small) refactor to get everything working again.

Just to comment that I already considered doing this, but was unsure whether it would be meaningful on things like `Finsupp` and `DFinsupp`, for which we could presumably attach exactly the same norm.
Same for the bornology.

Can you add this as a module docstring with `/-! ... -/` here, so that it's clear even when reading the docs?
```suggestion
-- throughout the rest of the file, we assume `1 ≤ p`
variable [Fact (1 ≤ p)]
```

Can you add some `example ... := rfl` sanity checks sometime after this showing the instances declared here and above are definitionally the correct ones? I.e., that after declaring the norm structure, that the uniformity and the bornology inherited from that are definitionally equal to the uniformity and bornology instances declared above? I'm relatively certain it is correct now, but I want to guard against future tampering.
This should be removed

Presumably this shouldn't be marked as a porting note.
```suggestion
```

Ditto.
```suggestion
```

Can't you just write:
```suggestion
    SeminormedAddCommGroup (WithLp p (α × β)) where
  dist_eq := fun x y => by
```
and delete the trailing `}`? (And then adjust the indentation too)

```suggestion
```
Maybe this should be stated earlier with weaker type class assumptions?

```suggestion
```
State earlier with weaker type classes.
as before, does this not just work with `where\n norm_smul_le := ...`?

```suggestion
/-- The canonical map `WithLp.equiv` between `WithLp ∞ (α × β)` and `α × β` as a linear isometric
```
I would put this section at (or near) the beginning of the file.
These `dist` and `edist` results could be stated earlier with weaker type classes
I've removed the assumption on normed spaces, but due to the structure of the proofs we still require a more assumptions than really necessary (otherwise we do not get the `nnnorm`).
I think this also works with weaker type classes. Presumably Pseudo(E? probbably not)Metric
in fact you only need the topological space instances, which are for free

nit:
```suggestion
    if _hp : p = 0 then
      (if f.fst = g.fst then 0 else 1) + (if f.snd = g.snd then 0 else 1)
    else if p = ∞ then
      edist f.fst g.fst ⊔ edist f.snd g.snd
    else
      (edist f.fst g.fst ^ p.toReal + edist f.snd g.snd ^ p.toReal) ^ (1 / p.toReal)
```
makes the trichotomy clearer
(same throughout)

`open Classical in` shouldn't be use for lemmas:
```suggestion
@[simp]
theorem prod_edist_eq_card (f g : WithLp 0 (α × β)) [DecidableEq α] [DecidableEq β] :
    edist f g = (if f.fst = g.fst then 0 else 1) + (if f.snd = g.snd then 0 else 1) :=
```
(you will have to fix the proof)
the problem is that the statement of the lemma needs the classical instance already.

@mcdoll I think you missed the change: `[DecidableEq α] [DecidableEq β]`, which means the statement doesn't need the `Classical`. The proof can be changed to `by convert if_pos rfl`. This breaks some other proofs which use this `simp` lemma, but then you only need to do `classical simp ...` in those proofs.
stupid me, fixed it.
idem
Can you use the same comment we use elsewhere, that clarifies which repo this issue number refers to (it's not #2220)
This should be in the proof not the statement.

```suggestion
@[simp]
theorem prod_norm_eq_card (f : WithLp 0 (α × β)) [DecidableEq α] [DecidableEq β] :
    ‖f‖ = (if f.fst = 0 then 0 else 1) + (if f.snd = 0 then 0 else 1) := by
  convert if_pos rfl
```
(untested)

Maybe nicer to read with `where` syntax:
```suggestion
def prodEquivₗᵢ : WithLp ∞ (α × β) ≃ₗᵢ[𝕜] α × β where
  __ := WithLp.equiv ∞ (α × β)
  map_add' f g := rfl
  map_smul' c f := rfl
  norm_map' f := by simp [Norm.norm]
```

```suggestion
  norm_smul_le c f := by
```
Is this needed?

```suggestion
  dist_eq x y := by
```
I think that all references to `ProdLp` should be replaced with references to `WithLp`, here and below.
`ProdLp` should be `WithLp`.
Instead of just commenting on the content of the lemma, could you first explain what the lemma says?
Ditto
I don't really like this name, as it is not obvious it refers to a prod situation and not a pi situation.

I don't see why you would make the variables explicit here while they are implicit in all nearby lemmas, which are of a similar nature. Note that making variables explicit is less useful in Lean 4, because we can always resort to named arguments if needed.
I would remove the `Zero` assumptions here, and replace in the definition of the norm the condition `if f.fst = 0` with `if ‖f.fst‖ = 0`.

Does this make a difference for pseudo-metric spaces? It seems to me that those definitions aren't equivalent, and it's not clear which one is canonical. I think this spelling matches what we do for `Pi`, and it would be best to br consistent

Yes, it does make a difference. In the `p = 0` case, the current definition of the product norm does not depend on the norm on each factor. My point is that it should, instead of depending on another unrelated `Zero` assumption.
And we should fix the `PiLp` file in the same way.

For instance, if you're taking the product of normed multiplicative groups, the point `0` does not make sense in the group. What makes sense is the point `1`, i.e., the one for which the norm is zero.

All the theorems in this section require different typeclass assumptions (you just need a `Norm` to give the statements on norms, and a `dist` to give the statements on `dist`), so it would be better to have something more fine-grained. Also, the `L^2` statements would probably fit better in the `ProdL2` file.

I don't think I agree with moving these lemmas; it means that these lemmas come with the extra import requirements of `InnerProductSpace`, which I suspect is reasonable heavy due to it requiring `IsROrC`.

for coherence with the norm, should it be `if edist f.1 g.1 = 0 then 0 else 1 + ...`? Same thing for the distance below. (If you prefer, I can do that in a later PR in which I would also change `PiLp`, because I wouldn't want to delay this one even more...)
no problem, this is an easy fix.

pullRequest.title: [Merged by Bors] - feat(Analysis): add WithLp for products
